repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - First-Fifth Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Vietnam First Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit Project was as follows: outcomes
            for the first project were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satsifactory.
            Ratings for the Vietnam Second-Fifth Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Projects were all as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low to
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satsifactory.  Some lessons learned
            included: 1) a stable macroeconomic and political
            environment contributed greatly to the successful
            implementation of difficult structural reforms in Vietnam;
            2) overall, progress was slower in policy areas
            characterized by limited political will, conflicting
            institutional responsibilities or insufficient analytical
            work; 3) an effective coordination mechanism is essential to
            overcome the logistical challenges posed by a wide ranging
            and cross-cutting policy dialogue; and 4) the Vietnam
            experience demonstrates that poverty reduction support
            credit programs, with very low conditionality, are a
            well-suited aid instrument in countries with strong
            government ownership of the reform agenda and its capacity
            to deliver in practice.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, sustainability, and performances by both the Bank
            and Borrower, with substantial institutional development
            impacts. This simplified Implementation Completion Report
            conveys the following findings and implications for
            subsequent operations. A stable political environment
            contributed to the continued, successful implementation of
            macroeconomic and structural reforms in Vietnam. Building a
            broad-based consensus and strong government commitment
            through the preparation of the Comprehensive Poverty
            Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS), minimized the risky
            (and potential) erosion of political support, and the
            likelihood of policy reversals due to political changes. The
            availability of technical assistance grants from donors, and
            strong and close Bank team support, plays a key role in
            low-income countries with weak technical working level
            capacity, especially in reforms in the State-owned
            enterprises (SOE), and banking sectors. The continued
            efforts within such coordination, proved successful in both
            project design and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Viet Nam - Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit (PRSCIII) Project seeks to implement Vietnam's
            Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS),
            and, provides further support to Vietnam's reform
            program. The project shall strengthen the reform program on
            several fronts: 1) promotion of greater internal and
            external competition, to endorse an acceleration in the
            divestiture of State-owned enterprises (SOEs) and
            State-owned commercial banks (SOCBs). Additionally it aims
            at improving transparency and accountability in SOE
            operations, and in the banking sector, while supporting the
            establishment of a sound regulatory framework for policy
            lending by the Government. These measures should improve the
            allocation of resources, economic growth and job creation.
            2) The project will also promote human development, through
            an expanded budget appropriation, and higher quality
            standards for education, through resources for health care
            costs of the poor, and through mechanisms to complete the
            transfer of land-use rights to households, especially in
            upland and ethnic minority areas. Further measures will
            improve environmental and water resources management. 3) In
            an effort to build modern governance, increased transparency
            and accountability of public finances, simplified
            administrative procedures, and steps towards curbing
            corruption will be pursued. Other actions aim at revamping
            planning processes, moving towards the alignment of
            policies, and resources to attain well-specified development
            goals. However risks include financial aspects, and
            governance practices, particularly as it regards the
            incomplete structural reform, which could jeopardize growth
            and stability in the long term. Also, the introduction of
            market forces in the social sectors, and decentralization
            are pressing service delivery, leading to increased
            inequality, with a less inclusive growth. And, there is a
            fiduciary risk associated with this project, if inadequate
            progress on budget transparency occurs; however, the
            Government recently embarked in an anti-corruption strategy.
